awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology: Crop yield enhancement strategies
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2022, Broadening Participation of Groups Underrepresented in Biology. The Fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology.  Transforming global agriculture practices is critical to meet current and future food demands in the face of climate change, and necessary to minimize environmental impacts that damage terrestrial and aquatic environments, and ultimately affect human health and well-being. Current practices used to increase crop yields rely heavily on fertilizers that threaten the environment and weaken crop resilience. Understanding and harnessing the diverse properties of microorganisms that live in the soil near the roots of crops (called the rhizosphere) has the potential to help find new, more sustainable farming strategies. This research project seeks to understand a specific microbial process that has the potential to help plants better access phosphorus in soil. The investigator will determine if certain compounds released by bacteria (for example, phenazines) that liberate mineral-bound phosphorus can make a difference to plant nutrition. The results of this work have the potential to provide alternative strategies enabling the reduction of synthetic fertilizer application and increased phosphorus bioavailability for plants.  This project will directly broaden participation of groups underrepresented in biology by enabling the research of a Latinx postdoctoral fellow in Biology who will engage other underrepresented scholars through mentoring in the lab. The fellow will also work with the non-profit Clean Water Science Network’s virtual mentorship program to increase the network and mentorship skills of postdoctoral scholar participants at Caltech and around the country.

The fellow will test the hypothesis that microbially secreted phenazines can solubilize iron-mineral-adsorbed phosphate by reductive dissolution, subsequently enhancing plant bioavailability and uptake.  Single-species and microbial community studies in a gnotobiotic plant model will be implemented. Fluorescent microscopy techniques, reporter gene fusions, and gene knockouts will be used to visualize and validate the proposed gene regulation and biogeochemical process. Analytical techniques (LC-MS, ICP-MS) will be used to quantify phenazine production and plant phosphorus content. The fellow will gain expertise and training in microbial physiology and genetics, plant-microbe co-culturing, microbial community design, and state-of-the-art microcopy. Additionally, the fellow will gain mentoring experience through research and by contributing to a virtual mentoring program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During my postdoctoral fellowship at Caltech, funded by the NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology, I led research projects aimed at unraveling microbial interactions in the rhizosphere. These interactions are crucial for promoting sustainable crop management and minimizing environmental pollution. My research also pushed the boundaries of microbial imaging technologies, particularly focusing on how microorganisms respond to phosphorus limitation, a key challenge in agriculture.

One major aspect of my work was developing bacterial reporter strains to monitor microbial gene expression under phosphorus limitation. I employed techniques such as molecular cloning, RNA-seq (RNA sequencing for gene expression profiling), RT-qPCR (quantitative real-time PCR), and fluorescence-based assays to track microbial responses. Additionally, I conducted bulk-scale plant pot experiments to measure phosphorus uptake in various monocot crops. Using advanced analytical tools like LC-MS (liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry) and ICP-MS (inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry), I quantified nutrient changes, providing precise measurements that are crucial for understanding plant-microbe nutrient interactions. This work contributed to our understanding of microbial adaptations that help plants access phosphorus, aiming to reduce the need for chemical fertilizers, which often lead to nutrient runoff and pollution. By improving our understanding of microbial phosphorus cycling, this work can inform more sustainable and targeted fertilizer application strategies in agriculture.

A significant technological advancement from my research was the development of a real-time imaging system that tracked bacterial gene expression in the rhizosphere. This was achieved through light sheet fluorescence microscopy, which allowed high-resolution, live imaging of microbial activity in complex soil environments. A manuscript detailing this work is currently in preparation. Additionally, I collaborated with a colleague from the biophotonics lab to develop the CFAST (complex-field and fluorescence microscopy using the aperture scanning technique) system, which enabled continuous monitoring of bacterial gene expression under varying environmental conditions. This system was particularly useful in studying how microbial communities respond to dynamic nutrient availability. These technological advancements culminated in a co-first authored paper published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (PNAS) in 2024. These imaging tools are essential for visualizing microbial activity in realistic soil environments and have broad applications for improving agricultural practices. This work was presented at several scientific conferences, including the American Chemical Society Fall 2023, the International Phytobiomes Conference 2022, and the 2023 SACNAS National Diversity in STEM Conference.

One of the most ambitious projects I led was the Phosphorus Sensor Project, which involved an interdisciplinary collaboration between microbiology, chemical engineering, electrical engineering, and biophotonics. As project manager of a team that included 4 PIs, 2 external collaborators, 4 PhD students, and a postdoc, I oversaw the design and development of field-deployable, real-time biosensors to monitor soil phosphorus levels and relay data wirelessly. These sensors integrated microbial physiology with cutting-edge living hydrogels and CMOS (complementary metal-oxide-semiconductor) chips, allowing real-time soil monitoring for precision agriculture. Supported by the Resnick Institute, this innovative project has the potential to revolutionize agricultural practices by optimizing fertilizer use, ultimately reducing environmental impact and improving sustainability. I presented the project’s progress and results at various events, including the Keck Workshop at Caltech (August 2023), the Geoclub Seminar Series (March 2024), and the Rocket Fund Showcase (June 2024). The project is ongoing, has resulted in two publications from the team, and was recently highlighted in Caltech Magazine.

Beyond my technical work, I was deeply committed to mentoring the next generation of scientists. I mentored two graduate and two undergraduate students at Caltech, helping them develop crucial skills in molecular biology, genetic engineering, and environmental microbiology. Notably, I worked with students from underrepresented groups in STEM, such as participants in Caltech's WAVE program, offering hands-on research experiences and personalized guidance. This aspect of my work reflects my broader commitment to inclusivity and diversifying the STEM field.

In addition to my scientific contributions, I engaged in outreach through my leadership role as Co-Director, Treasurer, and Mentor at the Clean Water Science Network (CWSN), a nonprofit organization aimed at providing environmental science education to under-resourced Latino communities. By recruiting volunteers from Caltech, I helped expand CWSN's mentorship program, empowering students from diverse backgrounds to pursue careers in science. This outreach aligns with NSF’s broader impacts criteria by fostering engagement with underserved communities and contributing to public science education.

Overall, the outcomes of my research reflect both the intellectual merit and broader impacts emphasized by NSF. My work advances our fundamental understanding of microbial processes in the rhizosphere while contributing to practical solutions for sustainable agriculture. Through interdisciplinary collaboration, student mentorship, and outreach, I remain dedicated to fostering inclusive and innovative scientific research for the benefit of society.
